description: Nasturtium (Tropaeolum majus) is a flowering plant native to South America, but now cultivated worldwide for its colorful flowers and edible leaves and flowers. It belongs to the Tropaeolaceae family and is prized for its vibrant blooms, trailing habit, and peppery flavor.
varieties: Nasturtium, scientifically known as Tropaeolum majus, is an annual flowering plant native to South America. There are several cultivated varieties of nasturtium available, offering a range of flower colors, sizes, and growth habits. Common varieties include 'Empress of India' with deep red flowers, 'Alaska' with variegated foliage, and 'Jewel Mix' with a mix of vibrant flower colors.

sowingAndPlanting.sowingIndoorsDescription: Nasturtium seeds can be started indoors in pots or trays filled with well-draining potting mix. Sow seeds 1/2 inch deep and cover lightly with soil. Keep the soil consistently moist and provide bright, indirect light or supplemental grow lights. Transplant seedlings outdoors after the last frost date in your area.
sowingAndPlanting.sowingOutdoorsDescription: Nasturtium seeds can also be directly sown outdoors in the garden after the last frost date. Choose a location with full sun to partial shade and well-drained soil. Sow seeds 1/2 inch deep and space them 8-12 inches apart. Keep the soil consistently moist until seedlings emerge.
sowingAndPlanting.season: Nasturtium seeds can be sown outdoors after the last frost date in your area. They prefer warm temperatures and well-drained soil.

careAndMaintenance.growingDescription: Nasturtiums prefer full sun to partial shade and well-drained, moderately fertile soil. They are drought-tolerant once established and do not require frequent watering. Nasturtiums are generally low-maintenance plants and do not require fertilization.
careAndMaintenance.wateringNeeds: Water young nasturtium plants regularly until established; mature plants are drought-tolerant and generally do not require supplemental watering.
careAndMaintenance.soilFertility: Nasturtiums do not require fertilization. However, incorporating compost or well-aged manure into the soil before planting can provide some nutrients.
careAndMaintenance.pruningRequirements: Nasturtiums do not require pruning. However, you may remove spent flowers to encourage continued blooming.
careAndMaintenance.supportRequirements: Nasturtiums are generally low-growing and do not require support. However, you may provide a trellis or other support if growing climbing varieties.

harvestingAndStorage.daysToHarvest: Varies; flowers typically appear 6-8 weeks after planting.
harvestingAndStorage.timeToMaturity: Nasturtiums typically mature and begin flowering 6-8 weeks after planting, depending on growing conditions.
harvestingAndStorage.storageRecommendations: Harvest nasturtium flowers and leaves as needed for culinary or decorative use. Use fresh flowers and leaves immediately, or store them in the refrigerator for up to a week. Nasturtium flowers are also edible and can be used to garnish salads, soups, and other dishes.
harvestingAndStorage.harvestDescription: Harvest nasturtium flowers by snipping them from the plant as needed. Leaves can be harvested anytime for culinary use.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Cabbage
goodCompanionPlants.description: Nasturtiums are beneficial companions for cabbage plants as they can repel cabbage moths, a common pest that lays eggs on cabbage leaves. The pungent odor emitted by nasturtiums can deter cabbage moths from laying eggs, reducing the risk of infestation and damage to cabbage crops.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Radishes
goodCompanionPlants.description: Nasturtiums make excellent companions for radishes as they can help deter pests like aphids, cucumber beetles, and squash bugs. The strong scent and peppery taste of nasturtiums act as a natural repellent, discouraging these pests from feeding on radish plants. Additionally, nasturtiums can attract beneficial insects like ladybugs and hoverflies, which prey on aphids and other harmful pests.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Tomatoes
goodCompanionPlants.description: Nasturtiums are beneficial companions for tomato plants as they can help repel pests like aphids, whiteflies, and hornworms. The strong scent and spicy flavor of nasturtiums act as a natural insect repellent, deterring pests from infesting tomato plants. Additionally, nasturtiums can attract predatory insects like spiders and ground beetles, which feed on pest insects, further enhancing pest control in the garden.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Squash
goodCompanionPlants.description: Nasturtiums are excellent companions for squash plants as they can help repel pests like squash bugs, cucumber beetles, and aphids. The pungent odor emitted by nasturtiums acts as a natural repellent, discouraging these pests from feeding on squash plants. Additionally, nasturtiums can attract beneficial insects like ladybugs and parasitic wasps, which prey on aphids and other harmful pests, providing further pest control.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Potatoes
goodCompanionPlants.description: Nasturtiums make good companions for potatoes as they can help repel pests like potato beetles, aphids, and whiteflies. The strong scent and peppery taste of nasturtiums act as a natural deterrent, discouraging these pests from infesting potato plants. Additionally, nasturtiums can attract beneficial insects like ladybugs and lacewings, which prey on aphids and other harmful pests, providing additional pest control in the garden.

badCompanionPlants.name: Brassicas
badCompanionPlants.description: Nasturtiums should be avoided as companions for brassica plants like broccoli, cauliflower, and kale as they may attract pests like cabbage moths. While nasturtiums can repel cabbage moths, they may inadvertently draw these pests away from nasturtiums and towards nearby brassica plants, increasing the risk of infestation and damage.

badCompanionPlants.name: Beans
badCompanionPlants.description: Nasturtiums are not recommended companions for bean plants as they may attract aphids, which can also infest bean plants. While nasturtiums can repel certain pests, they may inadvertently attract aphids to the garden, increasing the likelihood of infestation on nearby bean plants.

badCompanionPlants.name: Carrots
badCompanionPlants.description: Nasturtiums should be avoided as companions for carrot plants as they may compete for nutrients and water in the soil. Carrots require well-drained soil and may suffer from reduced growth if they have to compete with fast-growing nasturtiums for resources. Additionally, nasturtiums' dense foliage may shade out carrot plants, further hindering their growth.

badCompanionPlants.name: Onions
badCompanionPlants.description: Nasturtiums are not recommended companions for onion plants as they may compete for space, nutrients, and water in the garden bed. Onions require adequate spacing to develop bulbs properly, and the vigorous growth of nasturtiums may encroach upon their space, reducing onion yields. Additionally, nasturtiums' dense foliage may shade out onion plants, further inhibiting bulb development.

badCompanionPlants.name: Peas
badCompanionPlants.description: Nasturtiums should be avoided as companions for pea plants as they may compete for space, nutrients, and water in the garden bed. Peas require support for climbing, and the sprawling growth of nasturtiums may interfere with their growth and development. Additionally, nasturtiums' dense foliage may shade out pea plants, reducing their access to sunlight and hindering pod production.

tipsAndTricks: Choose a planting site with well-drained soil and full sun to partial shade exposure.
Plant nasturtiums in containers, hanging baskets, or in the ground as ground cover or border plants.
Water nasturtiums regularly, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings.
Avoid over-fertilizing nasturtiums, as this can lead to excessive foliage growth and reduced flowering.
Deadhead spent flowers regularly to encourage continuous blooming.
Harvest nasturtium leaves and flowers for culinary use by snipping them from the plant. Both leaves and flowers are edible and have a peppery flavor.
Monitor plants regularly for signs of pests such as aphids and caterpillars. Handpick pests or use insecticidal soap as needed.
Watch for symptoms of diseases like powdery mildew and downy mildew. Provide good air circulation and avoid overhead watering to reduce humidity around plants.
Nasturtiums are known for their ability to repel certain pests, such as aphids and whiteflies, making them beneficial companion plants in the garden.
Use nasturtium flowers and leaves in salads, sandwiches, and garnishes, or pickle the seeds as a substitute for capers.
